titleStmt.title: Variants of the bound pronoun 3rd person plural communis
titleStmt.author: Veronika Engler

sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for the 3rd person plural communis bound pronoun.

revisionDesc.change: For EGY-___ there are no values found
updating references to Zotero IDs via update-bibl-refs.xsl

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Young and middle age speakers use the communis forms -hun (after vowel) and -un (after consonant) unlike old speakers who use -hum for masculine and -hin for feminine.
Young and middle age speakers use the communis forms -hun (after vowel) and -un (after consonant) unlike old speakers who use -hum for masculine and -hin for feminine.
-hun occurs after vowel, in comparison to -un which occurs after consonant. Jew speakers in Haifa are also reported to use -(h)in
-hin occurs after vowel, in comparison to -in which occurs after consonant
Also gender distintive forms -hum (masc.) and -hin (fem.) attested.
Also gender distintive forms -hum (masc.) and -hin (fem.) attested.
Also gender distintive forms -hum (masc.) and -hin (fem.) attested.
Also gender distintive forms -hum (masc.) and -hin (fem.) attested.
The author notes -on after both consonant and vowel. While a weak h is heard in the singular when pronouns are attached after a vowel, that does not happen in the plural form.
This reflex (which is used alongside /-hum/) is used only by the Baḥarna in the villages.
In Maltese orthography /-om/ is written as /-hom/.
həm, but h can be omitted when preceded by C
həm, but h can be omitted when preceded by C
